summary: Facebook Inc. failed to comply with the 2018 order requiring to remove the unfair practice on the use of user data and to publish an amending declaration requested by the Authority

the company made false or misleading claims about the privacy of Canadians’ personal information on Facebook and Messenger. Facebook did not limit the sharing of users’ personal information with some third-party developers in a way that was consistent with the company’s privacy claims. This personal information included content users posted on Facebook, messages users exchanged on Messenger, and other information about identifiable users. Facebook also allowed certain third-party developers to access the personal information of users’ friends after users installed certain third-party applications.
the company violated a 2012 FTC order in multiple ways by deceiving users about their ability to control the privacy of their personal information.

Facebook miseld the consumers during registration by emphasising the free nature of the service while not adequately informing them of the commercial use of their data. Facebook also carried out an aggressive practice by exerting undue influence on registered customers, who suffer, without express consent the transmission of the their data to third-party apps for commercial purposes. The undue influence is caused by the pre-selection by Facebook of the broadest consent to data sharing. When users decide to limit their consent, they are faced with significant restrictions on the use of the social network and third-party websites / apps, which induce users to maintain the pre-selected choice .

between 2007 and 2014, Facebook processed the personal information of users unfairly by allowing application developers access to their information without sufficiently clear and informed consent. Facebook also failed to keep the personal information secure because it failed to make suitable checks on apps and developers using its platform. These failings meant one developer, Dr Aleksandr Kogan and his company GSR, harvested the Facebook data of up to 87 million people worldwide, without their knowledge.

Facebook collects data on ideology, sex, religious beliefs, personal tastes and navigation, directly and indirectly, without clearly informing the user about the use and purpose. Facebook does not delete harvested data once it has finished using it. It captures and treats information for more than 17 months through a deleted account cookie after user deleted their account.

Facebook committed two separate infringements [about user accounts before its 2014 takeover of WhatsApp] by providing incorrect and misleading information in the merger notification form and in the reply to a Commission request for information.
